Headline: Customer Experience Research | User Experience Research | Consumer Insights | Market Research | Qualtrics | Project Management | Statistics | Economic Analysis | Management
Comment:
I hope the time will help the parents to overcome from trauma they are going through.
I agree AI and predictive models can bring some improvements in the survival of infants during birth. However I afraid it will be limited to economically well parents only.

In India significant reduction infant mortality rates can be made only when proximity of public health systems and its efficiency improves so it is accesable to every Indian.

Government is spending crores to the in the form of free medicines, vaccines, nutritious food suppliment for the both mothers,  and infants. Still it need lots efforts improve its efficiency and its proper distribution.

This effectiveness public health system varies accross States as well as by Districts.

Another important factor we should be aware, that most of the births will officially get noticed or registered when the birth happens in a any form of private or public health system, or when parents willingly or responsibly do it. According  registratiom departmen more than 7% of births not get registered in 2019 alone. When birth itself not get registered  or officially counted, the just think about the actual the statistics of still births or infants not survived.

This is not the news most people expect in this age of technology. 

While AI can help, it needs good data. Unfortunately, today the healthcare systems in India are fragmented and hence extremely challenging to get that medical data needed to train AI and then retrain AI with newer advancements.

India needs connected healthcare system, so that the data can be exchanged countrywide.  And AI can then to be used to predict health issues much earlier, which would result in timely remiditation and care.

Headline: AI for Health Equity | Founder | Transforming Women & Fetal Care
Comment:
Dilip Kumar I am Aditya from CareNX, a SINE IIT Bombay incubated company working on the problem to reduce infant mortality since last 10 years. We have developed a patented most advanced AI model + diagnostic device which early identifies premature infants and provides alerts/referals to health staff early on. We have been able to scale it across 1500+ facilities all across India, screened 5 lakh+ patients and reduced NICU admissions by up to 33%.

We are now working with credible organisations like ICMR, UNICEF, MIT Solve, Stanford Medicine, AIIMS and UN-ITU in order to open source some of our AI models for scaling across Africa. https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/meet-winners-2025-ai-good-impact-awards-jxa9e

Would love to get in touch to provide more details.

Comment: Prevalence of post partum depression is 22-30% in India. Sadly a lot of mothers who go through losing an infant and who go through miscarriages develop symptoms of PPD that are untreated and not recognised. This adds on to the misery parents feel of losing their children. We have seen patients who have been depressed for over 30 years. While we need strong practices to prevent neonatal infections and hence fatality, we also need strong resources for parents who do go through this trauma

Headline: Doctor I Public Health Policy I Health System I Indigenous Health and Rights I Nutrition I Health Care Innovations I Art and Culture
Comment:
Agreed. The loss of a newborn is heartbreaking, and even more so when we know so many of these deaths are preventable.
That‚Äôs exactly where startups like Janitri and Spotsense are stepping in with purpose and precision.
Janitri is reimagining maternal and fetal care through affordable, AI-powered monitoring tools that work in both rural and urban setups. Their wearable devices and dashboards are helping frontline workers detect early warning signs in pregnancies‚Äîpre-eclampsia, fetal distress, delayed labor‚Äîbefore they turn fatal.
SpotSense is another game-changer. They‚Äôre building low-cost, point-of-care diagnostics for neonatal sepsis‚Äîone of the biggest killers in the first few weeks of life. Using saliva-based biosensors, they‚Äôre detecting infections faster than conventional blood culture systems.

Headline: Engineering Microbiome for Therapeutics, Wellness and Diagnostics. Make in India for the World. Purely Personal Opinions and Thought Experiments.
Comment:
I am sure your intentions are good, but you are connecting unrelated issues.
a) Please look into SIDS (Sudden Infant Death Syndrome). We still haven't identified a definitive cause.
b) Our infant mortality rate has nothing to do with AI. It is primarily due to maternal malnutrition, which leads to premature births and sepsis. This is compounded by the inability of malnourished mothers to breastfeed, resulting in increased susceptibility to infections and stunting.

AI in Healthcare can make a difference, but WE NEED SERIOUS EXPERTISE. Fitness Apps are neither AI, nor do they solve any serious Healthcare challenge.

Headline: Data Analytics
Comment:
Dilip Kumar
This resonates deeply. I'm sorry for your friend's loss - losing a child is unimaginable.
You're absolutely right about the AI potential in healthcare, and I think the scope is even broader than the 2.5% post-birth mortality you mentioned.
Looking at the complete picture in India: out of every 1,000 pregnancies, roughly 169 don't result in a healthy baby surviving the first year. This includes ~100 miscarriages, ~26 stillbirths, and ~43 infant deaths. That's nearly 17% of all pregnancies.
What's particularly heartbreaking is how unprepared couples are for this reality. Most don't realize that pregnancy loss is this common, so when it happens, they're not just grieving - they're also completely blindsided and often blame themselves.

Headline: Normalising preventive mental health for young people
Comment:
That is difficult to read. My wife and I had a miscarriage very early in our first pregnancy, and that itself took a ton of resilience and external support to recover from. The death of a newborn -- gee, can't even imagine what your friend must be going through! 

This said, early health risk detection is a tough area to crack. Whilst it makes sense theoretically and everyone buys into it at a notional level, not enough money is being put on the table for such interventions to succeed at scale. 

This is, of course, speaking from personal experience of building Mindei's preventive and early detection tools from a mental health risk perspective.

That does not deter us from continuing to build, though. We need more voices and spaces to solve for preventive approaches - and hence, kudos to to you for everything you do.

Headline: On a mission to make tech, talent, and capital work together for progress
Comment:
We already have plenty of ways to identify and predict high-risk births/newborns. It‚Äôs honestly not rocket science. 

The real challenge has been implementation and providing quality care in a public healthcare system setting. This is the case even when the newborns are already identified. Data is often altered/missed to avoid admitting these newborns, to drive the hospital mortality rate down. 

There are proven solutions based on decades of research, but they are just not implemented well. Ansh is working on it. 

Early diagnosis of newborn sepsis is missing. But then the challenge is low-cost market expectation leaving less incentive to heavily invest in research. An advance market commitment might solve this though. 

Would be curious to hear if Rainmatter would be interested in supporting either

Headline: Senior Consultant @ Fortis Healthcare | Medical Research | Quality improvement | Healthcare Leadership
Comment:
Neonatal mortality remains significantly higher in rural India (~1.5x urban). While national rates have dropped to ~25/1,000 live births (2021 numbers). The urban numbers are not that drastic, but still alarming. It also shows variations in states etc, like in urban karnataka it is 8/1000. Neonatal deaths occur many times due to sepsis which is preventable by rigorous hygeine at hospital and home. While the urban areas have better private sector hospitals, rural areas mainly depend on government infrastructure which is deplorable in many states. Many NGOs are working on this part, teaching hygeine to parents and working on best practices in hospitals. Predictive power of death from sepsis in Neonates are high with guidelines available which doctors are aware of. 
So, I believe that neonatal mortality can be better prevented from best practices and pure hygeine , handwashing rather than AI models. More than that, the real place of need is rural india where penetration of basic technology is pretty low.
Just my thoughts as a subject matter person!

Headline: Founder & CEO, Previu | Leading Cancel the Cancer Foundation | Decentralizing cancer care across Bharat
Comment:
You're right, Dilip. More than 700,000 children in India die before their fifth birthday every year. Most of it is preventable.

We see the same thing in cancer. Over 70 percent of cases are diagnosed too late. And when that happens, there's very little anyone can do. But if caught early, survival can be as high as 80 or 90 percent.

At Cancel the Cancer, this is what we're focused on. Build systems that don't wait for symptoms.

Appreciate you putting this out there. It matters.üôè

Unfortunately this may be difficult as maternal healthcare is highly fragmented>getting continuous, reliable data may be a huge challenge> it easily gets lost out of the loop due to variety of reasons....preventive care is a sore thumb in AI. Headline: Director @ Maxinov | Patent Services & Comp Intelligence | Fractional IP Officer | 20+ Yrs Helping Law firms & Companies Build/Defend/Monetize IP | Help Offload Bulk IP Work | US/Europe/Asia. MAXINOV.COM | MOHDSUFYAN.COM
Comment: Absolutely resonated with this. Having spent the last 20 years evaluating innovations, patents, and emerging tech (large part of my work has been in health tech), I can say that predictive models, AI diagnostics, remote monitoring, and historical health data modeling do have great potential to improve outcomes. But I think the biggest challenges are not due to the absence of such technologies particularly in Indian context. In fact, in many cases the risk is already known to doctors, to health workers, sometimes even to the family. Yet the tragedy still unfolds. Because of gaps in awareness, social and behavioral factors, resource limitations, infrastructure constraints, and lack of action for some other reasons. These are systemic, not technological, barriers. That said, technology must still be built, and smartly. Not just to predict, but to integrate meaningfully into care pathways .

Headline: Co-Founder, Inkani Wellness | Writer ¬∑ Marketer ¬∑ Entrepreneur | Health & Wellness Domain Expert
Comment:
We have massive amounts of medical data across hospitals and clinics in India that lie unused. The big challenge is in building systems to collect and organise this data. If we can, the potential is huge. 

Rahul Gandhi talked about working on this in his 2019 campaigns but no real progress has been made by anyone in this area yet as far as I know.
